user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_add_to_fd_set_:
```c
int
MHD_add_to_fd_set_ (MHD_socket fd,
                    fd_set *set,
                    MHD_socket *max_fd,
                    int fd_setsize)
{
  if ( (NULL == set) ||
       (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == fd) )
    return 0;

#ifndef HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE
  (void) fd_setsize;  /* Mute compiler warning */
  fd_setsize = (int) FD_SETSIZE; /* Help compiler to optimise */
#endif /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */

  if (! MHD_SCKT_FD_FITS_FDSET_SETSIZE_ (fd,
                                         set,
                                         fd_setsize))
    return 0;
  MHD_SCKT_ADD_FD_TO_FDSET_SETSIZE_ (fd,
                                     set,
                                     fd_setsize);
  if ( (NULL != max_fd) &&
       ( (fd > *max_fd) ||
         (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == *max_fd) ) )
    *max_fd = fd;
  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (! MHD_SCKT_FD_FITS_FDSET_SETSIZE_ (fd,
                                         set,
                                         fd_setsize))
    return 0;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment as written is not inherently unreachable (it performs a runtime check and may return). Therefore Rule 2.1 is not violated by this fragment itself. A violation scenario would occur if MHD_SCKT_FD_FITS_FDSET_SETSIZE_ is a compile-time constant: if it always evaluates to true, the 'return 0;' statement is statically unreachable; if it always evaluates to false, the code following the if (the add-to-set and subsequent update) is statically unreachable.
